predicate.note: Frames file for 'cast' based on sentences in financial subcorpus. No access to verbnet. Comparison to 'cover' and 'create' and 'name'.

roleset.name: cover, throw

example.name: cast a pall
example.text: All this has cast a pall over Columbia Savings & Loan Association and its high-rolling 43-year-old chairman, Thomas Spiegel, who built the $12.7 billion Beverly Hills, Calif., thrift with high-yield junk bonds.
example.arg: Columbia Savings & Loan Association and its high-rolling 43-year-old chairman, Thomas Spiegel, who built the $12.7 billion Beverly Hills, Calif., thrift with high-yield junk bonds

example.name: cast doubt
example.text: That collapse, following on the heels of disarray in the market for high-risk, high-yield bonds, cast doubt on the entire takeover business, which has fueled both big profits among Wall Street securities firms and big gains in the stock market generally.
example.arg: That collapse, following on the heels of disarray in the market for high-risk, high-yield bonds,

roleset.note: I doubt this occurs except in these two idioms, and maybe flycasting (fishing).

example.name: casting call
example.text: *trace-1* Cast *trace-2* as Violetta Valery in a new production of Verdi's ``La Traviata,'' Ms. Gruberova last week did many things nicely and others not so well.
example.arg: in a new production of Verdi's ``La Traviata

example.name: usually adjectival
example.text: In fact, they've spent billions of dollars to boost the percentage of continously cast steel to 60.9% in 1988, from 39.6% five years before.
